content.title: Alerts
content.text:
Alerts
Alerts are banners/modals that communicate a message with a degree of urgency attached to it.
There are two key types of alerts: standard alerts and application level alerts
design guidelines: standard alerts
-	Alerts are to be designed to garb user’s attention to provide critical information needed in a context of use.
-	Standard Alerts, in general, are four types:

1.	Success Alert
The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that the action taken by them have been successful. 
The banner/modal carries a green encircled check mark to visually accentuate the success message. The banner/modal itself should have a neutral colour (grey/white).
2.	information Alert
The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that additional information is available about the context of use. 
The banner/modal carries a black encircled exclamation mark to visually accentuate the success message. The banner/modal itself should have a neutral colour (grey/white).
3.	warning alert
The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that the action taken by them have resulted in a warning with respect to the context of use. 
The banner/modal carries a yellow outlined triangle with exclamation mark to visually accentuate the success message. The banner/modal itself should have a neutral colour (grey/white).
4.	error alert
The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that the action taken by them have resulted in an error with respect to the context of use. 
The banner/modal carries red encircled cross mark to visually accentuate the success message. The banner/modal itself should have a neutral colour (grey/white).
-	Standard alerts convey severity and urgency in the following order: error, warning, info and success.
In case there are multiple subtypes (of each of the types mentioned above) all of them are shown before another standard alert type is shown. For example – multiple error warnings are shown before a warning alert is shown.
-	size?
-	Placement of alert 

Standard alerts could be place in multiple contexts including inside of components. 

-	Application level alerts are of three types: error, warning and info.
-	Application level alerts follow the same order as standard level alerts: error, warning and info.
-	size?
-	placement?
